data.text: ECB and Magyar Nemzeti Bank set up repo line to provide euro liquidity https://t.co/SZO1bMaFMU

de Guindos: The crisis is also highlighting the importance of macroprudential policy in safeguarding financial stability. This is a truly global matter and will require a holistic framework and effective coordination at global level. Read more https://t.co/JmLRJEepLp 5/5

de Guindos: To enhance long-term structural profitability banks need to thoughtfully invest and support digitalisation and the transition towards a low-carbon economy. The pandemic could be an opportunity for the financial sector to adapt to this new environment more swiftly 4/5

de Guindos: The financial system has been put under strain, though. While banks entered the crisis in a relatively strong position, their market valuations were hit hard. Pressure has also increased on the already weak prospects for increased bank profitability in Europe 3/5

de Guindos: The pandemic has caused an unparalleled shock to the global economy. Swift action by monetary, fiscal and prudential authorities has been crucial in stabilising investor sentiment and ensuring that the financial sector continues to support the recovery 2/5

Panetta on imbalances and vulnerabilities faced by the two countries: I welcome the additional voluntary policy commitments made by Bulgaria and Croatia when joining ERM II, intended to ensure sustainable economic convergence by the time these countries adopt the euro 4/5

Panetta on the establishment of close cooperation between ECB Banking Supervision and the national competent authorities in Bulgaria and Croatia: Participating in the banking union before adopting the euro aims to address potential weaknesses in a country’s banking sector 3/5

Panetta on the Exchange Rate Mechanism II: ERM II was introduced in 1999 as one element to assess a country’s convergence with the euro area and to test the sustainability of convergence before and after the adoption of the euro. The ECB plays a central role in ERM II 2/5

(THREAD) As Bulgaria and Croatia have simultaneously entered the banking union and the Exchange Rate Mechanism II, they may be able to adopt the euro as early as 2023, provided they comply with all Treaty-based convergence criteria, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta 1/5 https://t.co/URIO7QQlRA
Euro central and compulsory intervention rates for Bulgarian lev and Croatian kuna in ERM II https://t.co/JpeNWIqMDA

Hrvatska poduzima ključne korake prema uvođenju eura. Kuna je uključena u europski tečajni mehanizam (ERM II). Hrvatska će se pridružiti i bankovnoj uniji te će od listopada ESB nadzirati najveće hrvatske banke. https://t.co/II4yNwlEo6

България предприема важни стъпки към приемането на еврото. Българският лев беше включен във валутния механизъм II (ERM II). Страната се присъединява и към банковия съюз, като от октомври нейните най-големи банки ще бъдат под надзора на ЕЦБ. https://t.co/II4yNwlEo6

Joining the banking union means joining European banking supervision through close cooperation between the ECB and the Bulgarian and Croatian supervisory authorities. We are working with them to ensure a smooth transition to the new supervisory regime 4/5 https://t.co/BsXVtlIq8Z

The idea behind this and other convergence criteria is to create similar conditions to those in the eurozone. This helps the country prepare its economy for the adoption of the euro, while allowing for some flexibility 3/5

Participation in the Exchange Rate Mechanism II involves maintaining a stable exchange rate in relation to the euro for at least two years and is one of the economic criteria for joining the eurozone 2/5

(THREAD) Bulgaria and Croatia are taking key steps towards adopting the euro. The Bulgarian lev and Croatian kuna are being included in the Exchange Rate Mechanism II.
The countries join the banking union too, with the ECB supervising their largest banks from 1 October https://t.co/BVTV3O0hkM

Yves Mersch: We would like to acknowledge all the effort banks have put in to preparing for Brexit. We will continue to engage with all affected banks to ensure that they achieve their target operating models in a timely manner https://t.co/JFVakYMkO6 3/3

Yves Mersch: The ECB will not accept banks attempting to operate as empty shells. All activities related to European products or European customers should, as a general principle, be managed and controlled from entities located in the EU https://t.co/JFVakYMkO6 2/3

We take the effects of our monetary policy on pension funds and savings very seriously, says ECB Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel to the Dutch newspaper @NRC Handelsblad. But interest rates are mainly driven by long-term economic and societal trends, not by central banks.

Af Jochnick: Banks will need to continue to repair their balance sheets and tightly monitor and manage non-performing loans. As challenges to profitability become more acute, consolidation could offer solutions for reducing excess capacity and deepening the banking union 4/5

Af Jochnick: Our work with banks has become leaner, more focused and more pragmatic. We have enhanced off-site supervision and strengthened our efforts in the areas of crisis prevention and recovery planning. We stand ready to further adapt how we engage with banks 3/5

Af Jochnick: The supervisory flexibility we have provided has meant that some resilience indicators, such as buffers, may no longer hold the same signalling value, so these indicators need to be reconsidered 2/5

(THREAD) We must start thinking about how to maintain effective supervision during the crisis and which aspects will be crucial in determining the shape of the EU banking sector in the medium term, writes Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick in The Supervision Blog 1/5 https://t.co/xm0ZZB7j4M

The ECB welcomes the decision by 16 European banks to launch the European Payments Initiative, which aims to create a unified payment solution for consumers and merchants across Europe. Read the press release https://t.co/aTIKsKICbF https://t.co/LLxKXfnaBX

The ECB sees no obstacle to the Deutsche Bundesbank continuing its purchases under the public sector purchase programme (PSPP) after 5 August, Executive Board member Yves Mersch tells the Salzburg Global Finance Forum https://t.co/yjdrlxyEYz https://t.co/JcZ5AJ5wdF

Banks are stronger today under European supervision than in the previous financial crisis, says ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in #TheECBPodcast. Listen to the discussion with @MichaelSteen https://t.co/ziMbZCAxfL https://t.co/N8ITSZrRdw
Read the full interview https://t.co/a1wLf8FAkj (6/6)

Lane: Stabilising inflation at around 1% should not be discounted as a minor achievement. But it’s quite important to continue to push inflation closer to 2% as our ability to deal with this type of shock would be enhanced if we had a higher inflation rate. (5/6)

Lane on inflation: Our policies over the last several years have had a significant effect on the inflation rate. In the absence of the measures taken by the ECB, especially since 2014, we would be in a situation of much lower inflation, maybe even negative inflation. (4/6)
Lane: When you get reports of infections or reversals, prospects for consumer confidence and investor confidence to fully recover quickly are diminished. (3/6)

Lane: We think that the European economy and probably parts of the global economy will have partial interruptions, either precautionary or in response to outbreaks. It’s not just about the initial unlocking of the economy, it’s about that persistent interruption of economic life.

We think that the recovery process has started, but it’s going to take a long time for output to fully recover, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @Reuters in an interview. It looks like you can make progress but then there can be a localised problem. (1/6) https://t.co/iEKCwHEFhl

Fernandez-Bollo: We will not penalise credible consolidation plans with higher capital requirements, and we will recognise duly verified accounting badwill and temporarily allow using existing internal models in the calculation of capital requirements for the new entity 3/4

Fernandez-Bollo: We neither push for consolidation nor stand in its way. Nor do we favour a given business model over another. Well designed and implemented consolidation can help address the overcapacity and low profitability issues of the European banking sector 2/4

(THREAD) The ECB must ensure that banks resulting from mergers have a sustainable business model, comply with prudential requirements and have sound governance and risk management, writes ECB Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo in The Supervision Blog 1/4 https://t.co/4RYNZiwsDn
In its Guide the ECB clarifies its supervisory approach to consolidations involving euro area banks. The consultation is open until 1 October 2020 https://t.co/a2pJbvCMc2 https://t.co/CKE1NilMIp

Panetta: The coronavirus crisis will inevitably lead to structural changes. We must move from the first phase of the crisis – protecting our productive capacity – to the second phase: rebuilding and modernising the European economy. 
Read the speech https://t.co/kmQ8jEggM9 7/7
Panetta: Our reaction function should be clear: we will respond to any significant tightening in financing conditions for as long as the negative effects of the #coronavirus shock persist. 6/7

Panetta: Acting decisively was required in view of disinflationary risks and lower growth, but also due to the risk of “hysteresis” effects and the high degree of complementarity among macroeconomic policies in the current situation 5/7

Panetta: The effect of the coronavirus is likely to be disinflationary. The same forces that held down inflation for the past decade will continue to do so and the disinflationary effects of automation and digitalisation will offset the cost pressures from de-globalisation 4/7

Panetta: Tentative signs of recovery need to be taken with a pinch of salt. There are three main risks to growth: the synchronised global contraction, the recession spilling over from the sectors hardest hit by the #coronavirus crisis, and the lingering effects of uncertainty 3/7

Panetta: Demonstrating to the public that macroeconomic policies are in control is crucial in conditions of high uncertainty. Our measures have avoided fragmentation, dispelled tail risks and stabilised the economy, preventing inflation from falling further below our target 2/7

(THREAD) Downside risks are prominent, said Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @EIB and @ESM_Press Capital Markets webinar. But a pre-emptive and decisive policy response has put us in a much better position to avoid more severe scenarios 1/7 https://t.co/VZJ1DwHtcH

De Guindos: Banks should address the problem of low profitability. They should cut costs, make structural changes and increase efficiency. In many cases this ultimately requires consolidation, both at national and European levels https://t.co/kf4IJZ5P0J 5/5

De Guindos: To avoid a credit crunch, it was necessary to ensure that liquidity would reach banks and to activate the public guarantee schemes necessary to channel funds to firms. This has been done and liquidity is flowing 4/5
De Guindos: The ECB’s response has had a very positive impact on financial markets: it has helped to avoid fragmentation and a credit crunch that would have had very adverse consequences 3/5
